text: Thank you, Lakshmi, and good morning and welcome everyone.
I'm disappointed that I can't see you all in person,
but at least we can have some virtual communion.
It's better than nothing.
So I'm here to talk to you this morning
about my book, which as Lakshmi mentioned
was just published a couple of months ago,
and in it it features my press model, which was outlined
in the HBR that she mentioned, which sort of defines
a roadmap for making profound and sustainable change
on the issue of racial equity.
In the interest of time, because I
want to make sure that I stay close to my 20 minutes
that I have this morning, I'm not
going to go into deep detail, but I want to sort of highlight
each of these five steps.
The very first step to having a hope of a prayer of solving
racism or any problem, for that matter,
is knowing that there is in fact a problem,
and that seems pretty simple and straightforward,
but as you'll see in the next slide,
it's not the case that everyone in the United States
even agrees that racism is real and exists.
And until we acknowledge the reality and an existence
of racism, that's going to continue
to be an impediment in the resolution of racism.
The second step, once you know that there's a problem,
is to diagnose the root cause.
So, this would be similar to a doctor.
So sometimes you can be sick and not have symptoms,
such as some latent cancers, which is a problem,
because if you don't know that you're sick,
then you won't seek treatment, but sometimes people experience
symptoms, such as severe headache, nausea --
it's then the doctor's job to diagnose what's causing
your headache.
This isn't just an intellectual exercise,
it's actually a practical necessity,
because headaches can be caused by lots of things.
They can be caused by stress and anxiety.
They can be caused by dehydration.
They can be caused by coronavirus,
and sort of knowing the ideology of a disease
will inform the best course of treatment,
which is why there's an arrow for root cause
analysis to strategy.
Knowing the cause will inform the best course of a solution.
So, knowing that there's a problem and understanding
what's causing the problem are necessary but not sufficient.
In addition to that, individuals have
to care enough to want to do something about it.
A patient has to care enough about getting well
to even take the pills.
No matter how effective the medicine
is, if you don't take it, it's ultimately worthless.
And there are many white people in America
who may believe that, you know, racism is not really
a big concern of theirs.
They can be wealthy, male, heterosexual,
and may actually believe that, if anything, racism, gives them
more power, privilege, status.
But, assuming that people know there's a problem
and they're concerned about fixing the problem,
the next step is do you know what to do.
And, as I mentioned before, that's
the strategy that's often informed by the root cause,
but I think the most important step is number five, which is,
are you actually willing to do it.
Any strategy is worthless without implementation.
So, I'm going to go through each of these five P-R-E-S-S steps,
beginning with problem awareness.
So my colleague in the Business School,
Michael Norton, along with Sam Summers,
conducted a really interesting study about 10 years ago
and since then it's been replicated by the Pew
Foundation, by several survey agencies, the Ford Foundation,
and E Pluribus Unum, and then other empirical studies
that have been published.
And in his particular version of the study,
he asked a large nationally representative random sample
and that's important, because these results can generalize
to the entire population.
He didn't just ask high school freshman.
He didn't just ask a sample from West Virginia.
This is a large, nationally-representative
random sample.
And he asked them two very simple,
straightforward questions.
First question, how much racism do you
think there is against Black people in American society?
Second question, how much racism do
you think there is against white people in American society.
And he asked them to respond on a scale
from one being none at all to ten being
as much as you can imagine.
To make the story more interesting,
he asked people to look retrospectively
at previous decades.
How much racism do you think there
was against Black people in the 1980s?
How much racism was there against white people
in the 1960s, the 1950s, etc.?
So let me draw your attention to two interesting aspects
of the data here.
The first is that when you ask Black and white people
how much racism they thought there
was against Black and white people in the 1950s,
there's a high level of consensus.
Both Blacks and whites agree that there's
an extremely high level of racism against Black people,
as you can see from the two solid lines.
The mean responses between a nine and a 10
on a 10-point scale, with whites being the solid gray line
and Blacks being the solid Black line.
Similarly, both Blacks and whites
agree that there's almost no racism against whites
in the 1950s, with both Blacks and whites
putting the mean level of racism between one and two,
on a 10-point scale, but that's where the similarity ends.
The similarities end.
Overtime, whites are perceiving a very precipitous decrease
in the amount of racism against Blacks, as you can see,
by the steep slope of the solid gray line
concurrent with a steep increase in the perception of racism
against whites, which you can see
by the upward slope of the dotted gray line, such
that by 2010 those lines intersect.
What that means, ladies and gentlemen,
is that white people now believe that there's
more racism against white people than there
is against Black people.
I'll say that one more time.
White people, and you can say white people, again,
because this is a nationally representative random sample,
white people now believe that there's
more racism against white people than there
is against Black people.
Black people don't agree.
They think there's less racism against Black people
now, that we're sort of getting close to almost free.
There's less racism against Black people
now than there was in the 1950s, but there's still
a lot more racism against Black people
than there is against white people.
So, in addition there is deliberate ignorance or
motivated reasoning, which is the idea
that people don't know because they don't want to know.
And then we've also got cognitive biases,
the availability heuristic.
So many white people may see exemplars of Black success,
such as Barack Obama or Oprah Winfrey,
and then generalize that to the entire group.
There's also research showing anchoring bias --
that many white people compare the current state of race
relations to the past, and so they have a more positive
or optimistic view of where we are compared to slavery,
whereas Black people tend to compare where we are
to an ideal future, to Martin Luther king's dream,
for example, and still notice that we have a long way to go.
And then there's also people's late definitions of racism.
Many people see racism as an individual phenomenon
that's perpetrated by hateful people
rather than something that's more diffuse and systemic.
And they also see racism as being blatant rather
than something that can occur outside of awareness, intent,
or control.
Root cause analysis, where does it come from?
Again, there's a whole thesis that
could be written on the various pillars, origins of racism,
including, as I mentioned, history, structures,
the design, conditioning that goes along
with those structures.
But human cognition, in many ways,
the way that we're wired as humans
both cognitively and socially to form groups, or tribalism,
is amenable to various forms of bias, including racism.
And then third, there's this whole issue
of ego-threat, insecurity, and need for power.
There's a lot of research, including classic work
on the authoritarian personality, that
shows that at the heart of racism is fear.
And then the next question is now
that we know that, you know, racism exists and have
some idea where it comes from, how much do we care about it?
And I sort of identified three types of people.
There are dolphins, who are friendly, be pro-social.
They want to be part of a community, part of a group.
They want to do the right thing, the moral.
Then we've got ostriches who were sort of indifferent,
right?
They can bury their heads in the sand.
They're kind of apathetic.
They don't really endorse racism.
They don't really care about eradicating racism.
They're just sort of like, "What's best for me?
What's in it for me?"
So, these would be the individualists.
Dolphins would be the pro-socials.
And then we've got sharks, who are
individuals and organizations that actively
seek to create a hierarchy where they're
at the top of the food chain.
So these are people who have an active commitment
to inequality.
Based on research that I don't have time to get into now,
there's a suggestion many people think
that 95% of the world or 95% of people in society are dolphins.
It's not true, it's slightly less than half.
About 49% of people are dolphins, about 39%
are in-different or apathetic, what
you might call the ostriches, and about one in eight
are actively sharks.
So, what can be done?
Well, part of it depends on the individual,
and I urge organizations to take a multi-faceted approach.
Many organizations think that it's enough to just talk
and, you know, share stories and raise
people's awareness of bias and how their actions contribute
to bias, and I think that's a little naive.
Because, as I mentioned, there are individuals, about 12%,
that want inequality.
They have absolutely no interest,
and the research in social value orientation
shows that it's really hard to get competitors, or sharks,
to cooperate in the laboratory.
That there are people who are inherently
bent towards creating hierarchies either dyadically
or inter-group wise, and it's very difficult
to get them to cooperate.
So, for those individuals, you need a stick.
For people who are indifferent who
could go either way a carrot, with the help,
such as the business case to say,
you know, "If you behave in X or y way,
there's something in it for you,"
or, "There's something in it for the organization," or,
"We could increase our profits."
So, I think it's important to have
a tool kit with moral appeals, incentives
in the form of carrots, and disincentives
in the forms of sticks.
I think it's important to have policies or practices that
say, "This is what will happen to you if you behave
in X or Y way.
You can be dismissed from the organization,
you can be put in jail," whatever it happens to be,
and sharks only respond to sticks.
So, broadly speaking, there are three approaches
to interventions around diversity, equity,
and inclusion.
There are those that are aimed at the individual,
so these are interventions that change individual hearts
and minds.
And Calvin Lai, who's a professor at Washington
University, has identified a lot of strategies
that are aimed at reducing implicit bias
among individuals.
And what's really interesting is they did a meta-analysis,

where they looked at 17 or 18
different strategies and really
only three of them work.
And they almost always involve some form
of reconditioning of an individual,
so showing positive images of Blacks
and negative images of whites to sort of rewire people's
associations between Black and negativity and white
and positivity.
Or some form of close meaningful equal status integral contact.
Those are really the only ways to change implicit bias,
and even then, the change is often ephemeral
not lasting more than a day or so.
And then there are cultural approaches to changing bias.
This is the idea that we as humans in many ways are sheep,
and we look to others and to shepherds
to sort of tell us what is appropriate
or what is inappropriate.
And because we have this innate need to belong,
and this mortal fear of ostracism --
in prehistoric times ostracism from the group would have meant
almost certain death --
people are strongly compelled to want
to behave in a way that's consistent with informal rules.
What's powerful, I think, about the culture and the social
is that none of it is etched in stone, none of it
is law that says, you know, "You will go to jail
if you don't do these things."
The punishment is really social disapproval, and that's enough.
So there's a great study by Robert Cialdini and colleagues
where they asked people to conserve more electricity,
and they asked them what would be the most convincing reason
for doing so -- to save money, to save the environment,
or because your neighbors are doing it.
And people self-reported that their neighbors doing it
is the least compelling reason.
But then they put door tags on everyone's door
in the neighborhood that had one of three appeals.
They said please save more energy,
because it will save you 100 bucks a month.
Save more energy, because it will reduce your carbon

emissions by 3000
pounds a year, or do it
because 85% of your neighbors are doing it.
And then they snuck into people's backyards,
and they read their meters, and what they found
was that by far the strongest impact
on their actual reduction of electricity
was what their neighbors were doing,
despite the fact that people said
that that would be the weakest.
And then we've got institutional/legal.
These are changes in formal laws, policies, practices.
Just one example is Massport, which
is an agency here in Massachusetts that
owns billions of dollars of land,
and so they have control over which corporations
can build commercial skyscrapers, hotels, convention
centers.
They actually own Boston Logan International Airport,
and what they found was that everyone getting rich
in the seaport district, which is a very --
I think 15 years ago was really that, a seaport district,
where people would offload lobsters and tugboats --
but now it's this high-end district,
where we you know get lots of upscale restaurants,
hotels commercial office space, etc.
And it used to be that they would choose the proposals
based on whether they had the money,
based on whether they had the team,
and based on whether they had the right aesthetic and
functional design, but then they changed the policy
to add diversity and accounted diversity 25%,
the same as all the other characteristics.
And what that did was it forced developers
to look for women on architectural firms;
it forced them to look for structural engineering
firms that were owned by people of color;
and it increased the representation of diversity
from about 2% to 37% on average.
So finally sacrifice, are we willing to do it?
And often sacrifice involves managing tradeoffs.
So, you know, one example that I give,
and this is a study by Katherine DeCelles, where
it shows that the incidence of air rage
is higher in airplanes that have a first-class cabin,
because people have to walk through first class
in order to get to coach.
I didn't know that so didn't have problem awareness,
but once I found that out, that then presented
a tradeoff between the comfort and convenience of first class
and my commitment to human dignity,
knowing that I'm complicit in people feeling diminished
as they walk through first class to get to coach.
So, the question is which do I care about more --
the comfort and convenience or people's dignity?
And that's an example of what I call a tradeoff.
And, similarly, there are tradeoffs,
often for organizations between doing the "right thing" quote
unquote and doing what's easy or safe or popular or convenient
or profitable with enslavement being
the ultimate example of trading off the right thing for profit.
Similarly, organizations often think
that there's a tradeoff between diversity equity inclusion
and fairness or tradeoff between DE&I and quality.
So, when I ask people, normally in a classroom situation, which
is more fair, they say, B. And what
I hope they realize is that B is equity, A is equality.
So, equality is treating everyone the same.
Equity is treating people differently, but in a way
that makes sense.
At the heart of inclusion is the question
of how to treat differences, how to treat people differently
in a way that makes sense, and we can come back
to that later in discussion.
But then the second question in our --
in here is will diversity affect quality?
So, if we look at this graphic, one
could argue if we take height as a proxy for ability
that the short person is simply unqualified
to see over the fence and why are we propping up
short people.
But if we look at it this way, everyone has the same height,
but what's causing some people to be able to see the game
is an unlevel field, which we can call privilege,
and an unlevel barrier, which we can call discrimination.
The blue person has low discrimination
and high privilege, and it's for that reason alone
has nothing to do with their height
that they can see the game whereas the yellow person has
high discrimination and low privilege.
If that's the case, are we morally, legally obligated
to correct for inequities in the environment?
And then, finally, I want to just end
by saying the best candidate, because you often
hear this in organizations, is not a trait it's not something
that you can identify.
It's an outcome.
So I'm from Kentucky, as many people know.
I'm from Lexington, and we just had the Kentucky Derby.
And people show up at Churchill Downs thinking
they know who the best candidate is, who the horse is,
and they're willing to put their money where their mouth is.
They're willing to bet on it.
And, most people are wrong, despite the fact
that there's a long history for all of these horses.
There's a track record which could be called a vita.
They know a lot about these sources,
and they still do not know who the best
candidate is until the first nose crosses the finish line.
Here's the second thing about that.
Even if that horse wins the Kentucky Derby,
it still doesn't mean that that's the best horse,
because those same horses have to come back and win two --
run two other races in the triple crown --
the Belmont Stakes in the Preakness.
And often, most often is the case
that the horse that wins the Kentucky Derby
does not win one of those other races.
What that pretty much means is that there's
a statistical ban, which means you have a lot of good horses,
and there is no best, really.
I mean, every once in a while, once a century,
you have a horse like Man o' War,
in Lexington there's lots of streets named after, which
is just a legendary horse that no one could beat.
That's not an everyday situation,
usually you have a situation where all these horses are
good, and who wins on a given day
is pretty much up to chance.
And that's Sheldon Zedeck's notion of statistical ban --
that, if you have 100 candidates,
there are probably 12 of them that are interchangeable,
and if that's the case, then look at those 12 that are good,
do what you can do to develop them.
This is the role of the jockey, because the jockey is just as
important as the horse itself.
That's who you might call the coach.
And develop these individuals to realize their full potential
and stop focusing on chasing unicorns, if you will,
which is this whole notion of the best candidate, which
is ultimately a myth.
And so, I would argue that there is
no tradeoff between quality and diversity, thank you very much.
